DataElement.preferredName: Breast Cancer Diagnosis Indicator Yes No Indicator
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The preferred yes/no response to indicate if a carcinoma arising from the breast is present.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit.  Breast carcinoma may affect both females and males.  It is the most common malignant tumor and the leading cause of carcinoma death in women.  Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation.  The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter).  The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular).  Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route.  The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome).  The therapy of breat carcinoma includes surgery, radiation therapy, hormonal therapy and chemotherapy, depending on the type and extend of the disease. --2002._The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation._An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

The widespread use of mammography has contributed in the detection of very early cancerous lesions (less than 2mm in diameter). The most common site of lymph node involvment is the axilla.  Breast carcinomas infrequently occur in males (particularly elderly individuals and patients with Klinefelter's syndrome). Concepts.definition: A carcinoma arising from the breast, most commonly the terminal ductal-lobular unit. It is the most common malignant tumor in females. Risk factors include country of birth, family history, menstrual and reproductive history, fibrocystic disease and epithelial hyperplasia, exogenous estrogens, contraceptive agents, and ionizing radiation. The vast majority of breast carcinomas are adenocarcinomas (ductal or lobular). Breast carcinoma spreads by direct invasion, by the lymphatic route, and by the blood vessel route. The most common site of lymph node involvement is the axilla.

Concepts.definition: The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

An event, entity or condition that typically characterizes a prescribed environment or situation and determines or aids in determining whether certain stated circumstances exist or criteria are satisfied.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The preferred Value Domain to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The affirmative response to a question.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Conceptual domain that includes value meanings to be used for Indicator Value Meanings such as Yes, No, Unknown, No Applicable

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A caDSR representation term that is used to indicate a question with permissible values of yes/no

Concepts.definition: A response or indicator that can have a value of either yes or no.

ReferenceDocuments.name: 6702 Text
ReferenceDocuments.description: Has participant had pathologically proven diagnosis of breast cancer since last visit?

ReferenceDocuments.name: DCP-Text-1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Does this participant have a breast tumor?

ReferenceDocuments.name: CRF Text1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Is the patient a woman with initial pathologically confirmed diagnosis of stage I-III, hormone receptor positive, HER2-neu negative, invasive breast cancer?

ReferenceDocuments.name: ECOG-ACRIN -1
ReferenceDocuments.description: Did patient present with new or established pathologically proven HR+ HER2-metastatic breast cancer at the time of Step 0 registration?

ReferenceDocuments.name: ECOG-ACRIN - 2
ReferenceDocuments.description: Did the patient present with new or established pathologically proven HR+, HER-2 negative, metastatic breast cancer at the time of Step 0 registration?

ReferenceDocuments.name: ECOG-ACRIN - 3
ReferenceDocuments.description: Did the patient present with new or established pathological proven HR+, HER2-negative, metastatic breast cancer at the time of Step 0 registration?

ReferenceDocuments.name: ECOG-ACRIN - 4
ReferenceDocuments.description: Did the patient present with new or established pathologically proven hormone receptor positive, HER2-negative, metastatic breast cancer at the time of Step 0 registration?

ReferenceDocuments.name: Wake Forest - 1
ReferenceDocuments.description: History of Stage 0-III breast cancer diagnosis.
